Apr 14 2007 	fabulous hotel adjoining rooms	My family and I stayed at the Silversmith Mar 29 - Apr 4. The hotel staff was always courteous and helpful, especially Peggy the concierge. When I called the week before our visit to confirm the reservations (orig reservatns made in Dec), I told her that we were celebrating my daughters' spring birthdays. She arranged a surprise of balloons and a plate of cookies in their room the evening of our arrival. Also, Peggy suggested and arranged a flat rate limo for us from O'Hare to the Silversmith. The difference in cost for 4 passengers to take an airport shuttle vs. the limo is negligible, and it was wonderful to stretch our legs in a limo after being crammed in an airplane and crowded airport most of the day! It is difficult to find the hotel if you are not looking for it , but that was part of it's charm. The Silversmith feels like a club or private hideaway. We had asked for adjoining/quiet/non-smoking rooms and were placed on the 10th floor. The king room was spacious, with a roomy bathroom that had a large granite countertop and granite tile floor, the windows in the room were very tall and had deep sills that my daughter used as a window seat. There is no extra charge for in-room internet hookup, the refrigerator is empty for our personal use (no honor bar/weighing crap like at other hotels) and Mon-Thurs there are cookies and cheescake in the lobby. The hotel was in excellent repair, no peeling wallpaper; everything looked freshly painted; the hallways, rooms and bathrooms were pristine. I loved the Arts & Crafts decor; the rooms each had old fashioned desks with wooden chairs on rollers; armoires with usable drawer space. The crisp white duvets and linens and very high ceilings also make the rooms appear roomier. The adjoining double/double room was on the small side, but had the same large windows, high ceiling and large bathroom as the king. The location was great, too! We were first time visitors to Chicago and were delighted to find that we could easily walk to the Art Institute, Oriental Ford Theatre, Macys(formerly Marshall Fields with Tiffany dome!), the Bean, and Giordano's Pizza. We also felt very safe at the Silversmith and the adjoining area. You must have an electronic card to go past the lobby on the elevator and the card only lets you get to certain floors (for instance, my card wouldn't let go to the 3rd floor only mine and the floor below.). The El is located right outside the hotel, but that was never a problem. It was a novelty, not a nuisance, to see the El cars go by at night outside the lobby windows. I would recommend asking for a quiet room if you think the noise might be a problem. Cabs are easy to catch outside the hotel, also. I wasn't sure what to expect based on the conflicting reviews on ths site, but I absolutely loved the Silversmith. I called several boutique hotels before I made reservations at Silversmith, and I can tell you that the Silversmith has many amenities that others did not offer, including adjoining rooms on top floors (other hotels only had adjoining rooms on lower floors facing construction), free in-room internet access, free refrigerator, and because we were on the top floor we had complementary breakfast each morning. I can't wait to visit again!! (and I'm very picky)!

Feb 16 2007 	That was a Crowne Plaza?	I had nothing but problems with this hotel. Honestly, just send up another towel, why argue with me?After speaking with the assistant manager about the fact that my 2 night reservation was only made for 1 night(and that wasn't the ONLY problem, just the biggest one) he graciously offered me a room for way more than I had paid for the first night, knowing my itinerary left me too little time to change hotels. Dec 31 2006 	Great location good wheelchair access	My partner and I stayed here for four nights in May 2006. I'm a wheelchair user and chose the hotel based on price, location, reviews on TripAdvisor and the ability to check accessible room availability and book such rooms directly online. Other (especially Australian) hotels take note - the ability to check availability of accessible rooms and book these directly via hotel online booking systems is a real selling point for me, and probably other wheelchair users. It saves a lot of time and effort, and says a lot about a property's willingness to treat wheelchair users as real customers.The hotel facilities were good, and noise from the EL (noted by other reviewers) was not noticeable in our room. I felt the room was a bit dark in terms of decor and a little cramped with a wheelchair. The room accessibility was otherwise good (no roll-in shower though). Hotel staff were very helpful with obtaining taxis when required and made us reservations with accessible seating to see a show. Given that we arrived after a two-day train trip from Seattle, we would have appreciated a coin laundry for guests though.The location was a major bonus. There was plenty to do and see in easy walking distance (e.g. Art Institute, Architecture tours, shopping on the Magnificient Mile). I was very pleasantly surprised at how easy it was to get to major attractions and restaurants in a wheelchair.The hotel's onsite restaurant is a New York-style deli restaurant, which serves great meals and very reasonably-priced breakfasts. My non-observant Jewish partner especially enjoyed being able to order matzoh ball soup from the restaurant menu for room service delivery.Overall, a great experience and a hotel recommended for a Chicago stay.

Dec 24 2006 	Cold Shower	I only ask two things from a hotel: bed and a shower. Nov 12 2006 	very quiet room	Asked for a quiet room away from construction. Got room 814...which had no view, but was VERY quiet. 11' ceilings are wonderful. Had a long entryway with a wall blocking noise coming from the hallway. It's also in a corner, so not a lot of people walk by.The bed was very comfortable, as were the pillows, and the bathroom was a nice size. It was nice to have a mini fridge, too. The only problem was an inconsistent knocking sound coming from the bathroom sometimes. Nov 11 2006 	A little gem of a hotel	My wife and I have arrived back in the UK after a five night stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith in Chicago at the end of October and into early November.If you forgive the irony, this is an absolute gem of a hotel located in the jewellery quarter right in the heart of the financial district and in the Central Loop, 1 block south of the Marshall Fields Department Store (now Macy's). It provided us with an ideal and safe base from which to explore Chicago as tourists.After a lot of research and poring over countless Chicago hotel reviews, we decided to back the judgement of others and book the Crowne Plaza Silversmith via its own ICH website. What a great choice of hotel we made and one that is fully deserving of its high ranking on Trip Advisor! We think you will struggle to find a city centre (downtown) hotel anywhere with such spacious, quality and affordable rooms, backed by high cleanliness standards, attention to service detail and superb, polite but not over-effusive staff. For our part, we feel competent in assessing if staff attitudes are forced rather than natural. There wasn't a single staff member at the hotel, who did not acknowledge us on eye contact, smile when necessary and provided what we wanted when called upon. Truly remarkable!We decided to pay extra for a room with a seating area, having been the victims previously of undersized accommodations in San Francisco and Washington DC and we were allocated a spacious, yet tastefully decorated room on the fifth floor at the back of the hotel. It was spotlessly clean and well equipped and had a big comfy bed, superb bathroom with walk-in shower and marble sink surround, efficient airconditioning, and was a lot less noisy than we expected. We hardly heard the "EL" below and never once heard our hotel neighbours eirther side or above, even though the hotel was full every night.Two good restaurants are close by:1 - Italian Village - 4 blocks away - great food, superb decor, supreme service and all at a sensible price2 - Millers Pub - 1 block away - good food and service, extensive menu, excellent prices and a great atmosphere as wellWe will certainly visit Chicago again in future and stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith but during Summer next time.

Personnel that ask How is your stay? you have a chance to respond and get resolution then and there.Employees at the hotel are alert, hospitable, good communication with all levels of hotel empoyeesBathrooms had comfortable robes,Bedspreads looked clean without a historyPatrice Brazil, all the conceirges and front desk employees good.Peggi T, the conceirge youve read about on this site, i-s inspiring, and helpful, soul of the hotel - we didnt need special services but we were enriched by her presence and comments.Good quality in room coffee and coffee maker, fridge thats quiet, Free in room safes that Four Points hotels sometimes dont provide - helpful for storing passport, IDs, laptop.Excellent security - one needs hotel guest key card to access your floorEnough staff on duty at front desk unlike some hotels.No signature fragrance in public areas, as Starwood hotels has doneClean, fragrance free environs - no disguising hotel odorsDoormen are very efficient, they pay attentionHousekeeping staff really good - supervisors check, follow upNegatives:Shower head doesnt release strong torrent of water - it's ok.Adas Restaurant downstairs - best to skip this food thats an embarrassement to the taste buds - huge portions, reasonably priced, not very good food - with maybe the worst coffee weve had, food has too much deep frying, the corned beef tasted like turkey or ham corn beef, the noodle krugle overkilled with sweetness. Jul 13 2006	Unbelievable Hotel for the money	This was our 4th trip to Chicago, but our first staying downtown (in the Loop). The Silversmith Crown Plaza was an unbelieveable. There was a turndown service everynight, with chocolates my kids looked forward to. The bath rooms were huge for hotels. The intricate tile floors and high ceilings spoke a lot of the quality of this fine establishment. The concierge was extrememly helpful for directions, places to go, etc... I wish I would have listened to her when she told me how to get to the Science and Industry Museum. She gave me the bus routes to get dropped off at the front door of the museum. I decided on my own to take the El and found out the museum was 3 miles from the stop in a VERY rough part of town. All the time we were waiting for the bus to complete our trip, I was thinking "I will ALWAYS listen to the concierge from now on"! The rest of the staff are just as helpful. When we left we discoverd our van battery was dead and the staff jumped through hoops to find jumper cables and a vehicle to get me on my way at 0430 in the AM.
