Couldn't have been happier since it was a "Taste of Chicago" weekend and every price I saw on the web was $200+ for a hotel within walking distance to Grant Park.The 12 foot ceilings are great (you just don't see that anymore, thank goodness for old architecture). The room was very comfortable with a nice and very large bathroom. Free internet access was also a plus. Staff was extremely helpful, no problems whatsoever. I asked for a room away from the train tracks and was given a room on the 5th floor...I could barely hear the train go by, it wasn't a problem at all...but it's right outside the front door of the hotel if you need it! I read some poor reviews of Ada's (Deli adjacent to the hotel) but my family had breakfast there on Sunday morning and loved it. I used the valet parking and didn't have a problem with that either (it's expensive but you'll find that anywhere in the heart of the city).I would recommend this hotel to anybody who wants to be close to all the action in the Millennium/Grant Park area. We even walked to Navy Pier from this hotel but it was a bit of a hike. You don't pay top dollar at Crowne Plaza Silversmith but you definitely get the quality of a 3-4 star hotel.

Jun 16 2006	Labor Day Rocked at Wrigley! Thanks Silversmith!	We stayed at the Silversmith last Sept. (Labor Day) Checkin was fast, courteous and we were able to checkin early, this was great considering we just got off a long flight. The hotel Staff was very friendly and helpful, whenever we had a question about directions, they were more than happy to give us detailed directions and at times point it out.After we checked in, we found out Jimmy Buffet was in concert at Wrigley Field on Labor Day(also my Birthday) The tickets were sold out! We asked the conceigre if there was anyway she could find some tickets, she made a call got us great seats, cheaper than the face value of the tickets. I have always been a big Buffet Fan! Not only did I get to see Jimmy but on my birthday at Wrigley Field !! The concierge at Crowne Plaza Silversmith made it all happen!!The room was clean, quite, beds was very comfortable. Bathroom was very spacious and bright. Every morning we went and ate breakfast at "Ada's Deli" it was delicious, a big variety on the menu. Omelets are really good!This was my first visit to Chicago and it was beautiful! I hope to return again and stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith.

Jun 3 2006	No ComplaintsW	My husband and I stayed one night at the Crown Plaza Silversmith and purchased the "Art of the City" package through the Art Institute. We mapquested the route and had no problem finding the hotel. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful from the doorman to the front desk and consierge. We were very pleased with the room as well. It was absolutely spotless with a huge bathroom and lovely arts and crafts decor. We were on the 5th floor and the El was right below us but we agreed that we'd stayed in hotels with a/c units that were louder! It was not a factor at all and we slept great. We very much enjoyed our stay at the Silversmith.

Jun 1 2006	Beautiful Room Home Away from Home	My husband and I LOVED our stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith over the Memorial Day holiday. We stayed two nights and paid $161/night + tax + valet, through a discount broker in Chicago. The hotel was a little hard to find at first - our online map showed that the hotel was on the east side of Wabash, but it's on the west side. Heading south on Wabash, look to the right for flags between Madison and Monroe. I thought the location was great, if you want to stay in the Loop/Theatre District/Grant Park area (and just a 5 minute CTA ride to River North). A taxi ride from Navy Pier cost about $8. The neighborhood is great, not seedy, as it's in the North Loop area, but it does feels more "downtown" than Michigan Ave's "uptown". When we got in, the front desk staff asked us if we'd stayed with them before, and as we hadn't, they upgraded us to a Suite (retails at $529/night). Absolutely beautiful room. We had asked for a high floor because of the El running parallel with Wabash at about 2nd/3rd floors. We still heard the El at night, but not too bad, sort of like a whooshing noise. The bed was doublesheeted and we had white robes to wear. The two TVs, ethernet connection and refridgerator were excellent amenities and the bed was super comfortable. Our tall windows let in a lot of light and had a window seat too. The view was of another building though. We ordered room service for lunch one day, and although many reviews thought the attached restaurant Ada's Deli was bad, the pastrami sandwich we ordered was fabulous. The gal who answered the room service phone wasn't very pleasant though. Also, our valet took coins from our car - they tell you to remove valuables but I guess that translates to "or else". It was only 90 cents, but it put a damper on our experience. Everything else about our trip was dandy though and we feel like the hotel is our home away from home in Chicago - especially if we can get that rate again.

May 29 2006 	adequate but poor location	We stayed for two nights on a last minute trip. While the cost seemed comparable to Michigan Ave, the location leaves a bit to be desired. This hotel has an entrance below the elevated train, and really appears to be a nicely converted office building. We actually thought the GPS on our rental car was wrong and drove by the entrance twice before finding it. The neighborhood was a bit seedy, but we were able to find a nice Italian resturant a few block away (Tratttoria 10). The rooms are very nice, unique, and not at all like a generic chain. There are NO views.The staff are nice.They've done a nice job with what they've had to work with, but due to the location, we would not choose to stay here again.

May 11 2006 	A great find	I stayed at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith while in town for business and pleasure. This was one of the top Crowne Plaza hotels I have stayed at. The rooms were nicely decorated with oak trim, oak beds, and oak wardrobe/entertainment center. I had a King premium room, which was nice sized for downtown standards. The location was good - about 1/2 mile from Michigan/Chicago River and a block from Millenium/Grant Park. The L stops right outside and it is fairly convenient to the McCormick Place. Most of the good dining is North of the river, so a 1.5 mile walk or short cab ride will get you there quickly. I have stayed at the Palmer House, Hotel 71, Grand Hyatt, and some of the other 3* hotels in the area. This was far superior to those in my opinion.

May 10 2006	Enjoyed our stay at the Silversmith	Our experience at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith was very good. The hotel is within easy walking distance to Millennium Park and we thought our museum package was a good value (the room, free breakfast next door at Ada's Deli, and tickets to the museum). The room was spotless, the bathroom was large and elegant, and the mattress was very good. We were worried about noise from the El, but with the fan running, we slept right through it. Some of the ground floor staff are not very friendly, but most were great. The only disadvantage is the difficult parking in front of the hotel to unload, requiring several trips around the block until we could doublepark.

May 8 2006	Enjoyed this hotel!	Stayed at this hotel for a birthday weekend of theatre and shopping. We were very pleased. The staff from valet to desk to housekeeping was friendly and helpful. Peggy, the concierge, was excellent and had wonderful recommendations. The room was very nice with the high ceilings and very large bathroom. We did not hear the train hardly at all. As others have noted, the deli downstairs isn't the best food, but staff was pretty good. This would be one of my first choices next time we stay downtown.

Apr 27 2006	Cozy and Good Value	As expected, the taxi driver from ORD didnt know where this hotel is located so be sure to have the street address at hand. Staff at the second floor lobby was friendly and helpful. We had booked a suite on the executive floor. Suite 1005 has the best view of the lake, but the view is across some black roofs and I wouldnt fight for it. The noise from the train below was not disturbing at all but the refrigerator was far too loud for the poor guy (me) who had to sleep on the sofa bed. The rest of the room was very nice and practical. There was even a microwave and a sink  very useful for preparing baby food.Our suite was not very large, in fact it was rather cramped when the sofa bed was in use. Also, there is no window in the living room and no door between bedroom and living room. But there are two TV sets.Continental breakfast at the club lounge was ok. There are only two cocktail tables and eight chairs in the lounge although we were always lucky with space.While both the suite and the executive lounge were nothing to write home about, it must be added that the surcharges for suite and executive were minimal. So at the end, it was a great value for a family of four. A very comfortable place and a perfect location.

Apr 11 2006 	Beware on ground floor	Beware of pickpockets in the lobby and front of the hotel..The Hotel Lobby is not on the Ground Floor and you enter into a smallish entrance. I have stayed here before but this was a red flag for us not to return.Hotel management were told of the problem but seemed to be annoyed with us not the pickpockets.
Feb 27 2006	Exceeded expectations	Great convenient location. Helpful staff. Rooms were spacious and very clean. Ada's restaurant/deli/bar connected on the ground level was good with pleasant staff.

Jan 12 2006	Great Hotel	We stayed with our 2 children for a weekend in December. It has a perfect location to visit Millenium Park, the museums, & the holiday decor at Daley Plaza & Marshall Fields. We arrived & were upgraded to a club level room. (only complaint, not much room for all of the guests to sit in the continental breakfast area) The beds were comfortable & the bathroom was huge for a city hotel. We only heard the swoosh of the L while awake, no one noticed it at night. Ada's was convenient for an evening cocktail or breakfast in the morning. We would definitely stay here again.

Nov 16 2005	Good value in the Loop	3-night stay over Veteran's Day weekend. Got a 10th floor executive room with breakfast coupons for Ada's next door, average price $229 a night (Thurs-Sun.) Ada's food is lousy, we ate there the second morning because the continental breakfast offered to 10th floor guests was in a small, uncomfortable room with a TV blasting. (Another disappointment: I assume an "executive lounge" would be available evenings and whatnot - it's not, only open for breakfast.)The desk staff was borderline rude when we arrived an hour before official check-in time, and had us trudge back downstairs with our suitcases to give them to the bellman. Our terrible first impression was fortunately mollified by the quality of the room once we were allowed in. The construction is solid; we never heard a sound from either occupied room next to us. These are not rooms for families, but they're perfect for a couple. Location is good, with easy access to subway, El and buses. Millenium Park and Art Institute are only a couple blocks away.

Nov 7 2005	Great Room Close to Theater and shopping	This hotel was one of the more reasonably priced ones in the area around the theater district. The hotel is one block from Michigan Ave. and only a couple blocks from the theaters! Our room was ready when we asked to check in early. Our room was gorgeous. The beds were comfortable and I love all of the products that they offer in order for you to get a good night's sleep! The bathroom was HUGE!! I loved it! The shower head was disappointing. It was one of those massage ones set on a horrible setting and I couldn't reach to fix it. Housekeeping came and asked if we wanted turn down service. We could hear the train, of course, but it was not that bad. The desk clerk who checked us in was not exactly friendly but she wasn't rude either. She got the job done quickly and efficiently. The concierge did not seem friendly but we did not actually talk to her so I can't say for sure. Most of the bellhops/valets were very friendly and they are the first people you encounter when entering the building. We will definitely stay again!!!

Nov 5 2005	I couldn't have asked for more...	My sister recently came to visit from England for a visit. I chose the Silversmith because of the great reviews on this site!A few days before our stay I called Peggy the concierge and made a few requests. As it was my sister's birthday I wanted the stay to be memorable. When we arrived at the hotel our suite was ready! Not only were all of my requests met, but there was a bottle of white wine chilling with a birthday card for my sister! I couldn't have asked for better service! All of the staff and ammenities were perfect.My only complaints:1. I called the hotel before booking online because I wanted a two room suite (one bedroom with a sleeper sofa behind the french doors.) Upon checking in I found we only had a one room suite. This was a bit of an upset as we had three people sharing the room and wanted a little bit of privacy. However, it was nice anyway.2. We had breakfast at Ada's next door. The coffee was weak, the hashbrowns were cold and they didn't care. My main portion on breakfast, the Beneditct Arnold was perfect, but I'll never visit again. There's a 'Corner Bakery' one block south next to the Palmer House Hilton. Go there for breakfast, save yourself $5.00 per person and be much happier!

Oct 27 2005 	I am down-grading my rating but still a nice place	This was my third stay here, and I'm a little disappointed about this last trip. First, prices have gone up significantly; it's still a fine "value," but our "suite" was on par price-wise with a nice room at the Renassaince/Westin-types. When we landed at the airport, I called to ask the El Stop to detrain. I was calling on my cell. The woman who answered said, Yadda, yadda, "I'm with a guest now, please hold." So I held. 5 minutes later, I hung up. I tried again, same thing. And I held. I called again later, as we were now getting closer to downtown and I was a little nervous. Same answer, so I shouted out "I just have the quickest question," and she started arguing with me! You can tell I'm peeved about this. It's b/c service here used to be so wonderful, and there were always plenty of staff in the past. I had chalked it up to a single problem until I was at the desk later that day and the staff person did the same thing. I told her it was okay with me to attend to the caller, which she did (I have no idea if it was the same person).This was our first stay in a "suite" here. True, two rooms, which was our goal. However, and I guess this is in keeping with Prairie style, the wall between the two rooms is 3 feet shorter than the ceiling. This defeated the purpose of having a separate work space for me apart from my husband. Too loud.Gym is 3 aerobic machines. Not a big deal in nice weather, as you are a block from the walking areas, but that's 6 months of the year that are touch-and-go.Business Center is $5 to use (each time), and only one computer prints. If you stay on 10th floor with the breakfast room, the servers are TOTALLY stressed out on weekends (but they're sweet). Bagels weren't even bagels, stale bread in square bagel form. But the zucchini bread was awesome. Coffee very good.Location is still prime, prime, prime. And not nearly as expensive as the Palmer House.I had felt the pleasure of staying here was in part the service, and I found that lacking this time. Hopefully, it was just a passing phase.

Oct 25 2005 	Nice Hotel - close to the el and the Sears Tower	I stayed here October 24th for one night. My room was not ready so I stored my luggage and went to my office building in the Sears Tower. I took a cab to the tower - it took about 5-10 minutes, but walked back (about 10-15 minutes).When you walk in you see the bell hop on the first floor and take the elevator up to the second floor lobby. The decor is fresh and appears to be recently renovated. Ceilings throughout the hotel are very high and leave you with a very "open" impression. My work travel agency had booked me a smoking room so I switched to a non-smoking, wheelchair accessible suite on the 4th floor. I also requested a room AWAY from the el - very important here. The suite was very large and had recently been remodeled. I did not hear the train at night and only heard "whooshing" sounds the next morning. The bathroom was huge with granite countertops. The fitness center is open 24 hours. It is small and has about 4 cardio machines and a Precor cable machine, but it was fine. There is a flat screen to entertain you while you exercise. I usually stay at the W on Adams St. but the rooms there were sold out. I would definitely stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith again.

Oct 13 2005 	Great!	Three night stay for a conference, cute room with a little nook with a desk area. The train was right below my window but I couldn't really hear it, the windows are double panes, just sounded like a woosh of wind now and again. A good experience all around, and the train is actually a great benefit, took it in from midway airport and the stop is directly outside the front door of the hotel. Bathroom was larger than most hotels, rooms were spotless.

Oct 3 2005	Easy from the airport and close to the Park	Great for the money and very well situated to go to Millenium Park and to take the train from O'Hare. It's not as good to get to Miracle Mile and that area, but there are plenty of cabs. As compared to other hotels of its quality, it's far cheaper. The concierge was just great and got us on the Architectural Tour about 15 minutes before it left. She was amazing. The whole Chicago experience was a brilliant one.

Sep 21 2005 	Still An Excellent Hotel for the Monay	We stayed here for 4 nights this month and were not disappointed during our second visit. Room was clean, well appointed and the staff was excellent. Restaurant was very good for breakfast, lunch and dinner (if you like a diner-type New York-deli style food -which we do). Crowne Plaza also now offers ear plugs, eye shades, lavender linen spray and a relaxation CD in the room so any EL noise is a moot point. Only complaint is there is no parking (not that I would normally rent a car in Chicago but I had to drive to Milwaukee for a day) and the valet parking available was expensive and inconvenient since they park the car several blocks away. I waited about a half hour for the car and I called ahead 10 minutes before. What a waste of time. Otherwise the staff is excellent and the room is definitely a good deal in a great location.

Sep 16 2005	Watch out! This hotel double billed my credit card!	I booked this hotel through Orbitz. I Had a nice stay at the hotel but when I got home there was a little surprise when I got my credit card statement. This hotel had double billed my credit card! Orbitz billed me for the room and so did the hotel. So far I have not gotten a satisfactory response from this hotel or Orbitz. I have spent hours on the phone being put on hold, trying to get this issue resolved. Be careful!

Sep 12 2005	good value	We stated at the silversmith on the executive 10th floor the noise from the el was no greater than normal road noise. The service was very good and the suite of a good size. compared to the hotels on michigan and in river north you definitely get a lot more for your money.

Sep 5 2005	Friendly Staff!	The staff is what really sets this hotel apart from other downtown Chicago hotels. They are always cheerful and helpful. Our room on the 10th floor even had a minor lake view at no extra charge. Most hotels (i.e. The Drake) would charge extra for a sliver of lake view. Not here! The "El" train outside the front door just adds to the downtown Chicago experience. You can hear it in the room but it's not very loud at all. The area seems very safe as long as you use common sense. We recommend The Big Downtown restaurant one block south. Millenium Park was great! Many of the reviews say the same thing but I would like to comment on a few minor negatives for you: The wall dividing our suite into 2 rooms only went about 75% of the way up to the ceiling (for air circulation?!). Provides privacy but not sound insulation between the two t.v.s. Also the lack of a pool is a bummer if you have kids. The cable t.v. channel selection is poor also; not even the Disney channel! If a hotel doesn't have a pool for the kids at least have the Disney channel! There was no bedding for the sofa sleeper in our room. Usually it is found in one of the drawers, some hotels will even have the bed made up in the sofa when you flip it out!. Had to wait 20 minutes for it to be brought up. Our floor had a lounge with a continental breakfast which was just pastries and juice. Overall a GREAT hotel!

Aug 26 2005	Tremendous!	I came to Chicago with my mother for three days -- the sole purpose of our trip being a U2 concert. I chose this hotel primarily based upon this sites glowing reviews, and it's close proximity to the United Center. We were both incredibly pleased.As I'm lazy and did not want to drag luggage on the El, we opted for the airport shuttle service, which I believe was 30 dollars per person (the price varies slightly according to hotel, and since the silversmith is downtown, it was one of the more expensive stops). Although we arrived at the hotel three hours prior to check in (my genius self forgot to allow for the hour back time change), the staff promptly lead us to our room. About an hour after our arrival, we recieved a call from the concierge asking us if we were pleased with our room. We were in the back on the 4th floor. While we faced a brick wall, we didn't have any problems with noise from the El (although, as I live in Manhattan, I can pretty much sleep through anything). The rooms were spacious (high ceilings were a nice touch), and I only wish I had that bathroom in my apartment. There was a good size desk in the room (good for business travelers), and free high speed internet (as my laptop is glued to my hip, this was a much appreciated amenity). We also recieved evening turndown service, even though we didn't request it, and the front desk was very prompt in replying to my request for feather pillows. We ordered room service for breakfast one morning, and as noted by another reviewer, their potato pancakces were excellent. The portions were also very large -- a little too large. The concierge also called up about five minutes after our food was delivered to ask us if we were pleased with our meal. Unfortunately, as we weren't there for long, we didn't have time to do much site seeing. We did walk to Millenium Park one night, which was quite lovely. I never felt unsafe walking around the surrounding area of the hotel -- as with any large city, just exercise common sense and stay alert. A bus to the United Center also stops diagonally across the street from the hotel.There was a young female concierge there who was definately on too many happy pills -- her ear to ear smile was just a little too eager to please. We did recieve a reccomendation for a pizza place from her (Giordano's -- not bad, but I'm still partial to NY pizza ;). It was also Mother's Day weekend, and they had some free desserts in the lobby for all Moms.I certainly hope to return to Chicago soon, and will most definately stay at the Silversmith. It was an absolute pleasure!

Aug 23 2005	Superb room location and service	I have stayed at numerous hotels in downtown Chicago: Essex, Palmer House, Almafi, Intercontinental, Club Quarters, Hyatt Regency, Best Western, Holiday Inn, Hotel 71, and a few others I can't recall. The Silversmith is in the top of the group in my opinion.A group of 8 of us arrived at 9:00am on a Friday morning and all were able to check-in to our 3 rooms that early. On top of that, we were each given an upgrade to a king suite at no extra charge. Another group came later and received a regular king room. The regular king room was spacious with high ceilings. The king suite I was in had 2 seperate rooms with high ceilings. The bed was comfortable. I was next to the L on the 6th floor. I could hear it, but it wasn't loud enough to keep me awake. Maid service was good. The bellman were very helpful with advice on blues clubs, bars, restaurants, and transportation. Friendly guys. There is a restaurant/bar downstairs open until 3am on the weekends. Good food (according to a few members of our group). A block south is a Corner Bakery with great breakfast. A block north is a Garretts popcorn for the best popcorn anywhere. Different L stations are very close enabling quick/easy travel nearly anywhere in the city.Only problem with the hotel occured when I came home and there was a charge on my card. It took a few calls before I found out I was charged for a robe. Took a few more calls to finally get the charge taken off. The robe had been thrown in with the dirty towels. Understandable mistake but became difficult to get the issue resolved. Although, it was resolved in the end and I thank the management for resolving the issue. Could happen at any hotel. I am really glad they took the charge off because I didn't want to have a reason to not go back to this great hotel in Chicago.

Aug 7 2005 	The Best Value in Chicago!	This hotel is excellent! We only stayed one night at the Silversmith and then moved to the Four Seasons (that was on someone else's dime) for the next three nights...and, I liked the Silversmith better! It was $300 less per night too. The staff was so friendly, they let us check in early, held our bags for a few hours after we checked out, and made a fuss over our kids.The location is pefect. We walked to the museums and Millenium park. We also walked to the restaurant district, but that's not close, or you can take a cab for $6. Oh, we took the El from the airport (The El is $1.75 or a $45 taxi ride) and the stop is right at the door of the Silversmith, couldn't of been easier. You can hear the El sometimes (we were on the 10th floor) but after awhile you don't even notice.The breakfast had something for everyone, the room it was served in was just a little small. Silversmith also provided nice terry robes and turn down service. I highly recommend this hotel and we will stay here the next time we come.

Aug 1 2005	way above and beyond	I have never bothered to post a review of a hotel before, but our recent stay (July 20-23) at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith was so wonderful I feel compelled to comment. We snagged a $168 a night on-line price from the hotel's website on the tenth floor executive level after reading reviews here about a higher level room being preferable because of the El outside. (We never heard a train once in our three days). The room came with the complimentary exec lounge breakfast but because we like to do the big breakfast thing when we travel, we tried downstairs at Ada's the first day (Good but too expensive $73 for four) and the second day, at Peggy the Concierge's recommendation, a good place down the block in a spiffy art deco building. Sorry can't remember the name but it was just a block north on the opposite side of the street. It had the feel that some young GI from WWII whistling a Glenn Miller tune with a few hours between trains to his next posting might just walk in to have a cup of joe and eggs and bacon. Perfect. The two great things about the service at the Silversmith:1) When our bags were brought up to our room our 11 yo son was complaining to me that he wanted jam with a croissant we brought from the airport. Well, I don't ordinarily travel with pots of jam and told him so. So he said to the bellman, "Do you have any jam?" I could have smacked him, but the guy said, "Would you like grape or mixed berry?" Huh?He whipped out the door, tipless, and returned with both varieties on a tray, with napkins, and a knife. Whoa!2) While we were working on dinner reservations, the aforementioned Peggy the Concierge found out that we were in Chicago for our 20th wedding anniversary (and to see the Red Sox play the White Sox). An hour or so later when my husband and I were down at the bar at Ada's, she sent up about a dozen warm cookies, two in-room movie passes for the our twin boys, and a card to the boys and a card to us.Yes, the room was small for four people. But it was nice and the bath was properly-sized. I don't expect a big room in an older city hotel. As others have stated in their reviews, they do give you ear plugs, but having stayed in the Crowne Plaza UN at 2nd and 42nd in New York many times for business, I know that the ear plugs and lavendar spray are a Crowne Plaza thing and not just because of the proximity to the El.The neighborhood felt completely safe for a family with kids day and night and we were able to walk just about anywhere we wanted to go. Public transport was close by to take us down to U.S. Cellular Field to see the game. Strangers were weirdly (we're from New England) and pleasantly friendly throughout our stay. The only exception was this Madame Mao chick who took control of the taxi line after the game with an iron fist. But she was probably from out of town too.

Aug 1 2005	Excellent stay at the silversmith	I stayed in a suite on the tenth floor. The room very quiet and spacious and the service was superb. The breakfast that came with the room was very good and the complementary cheesecake was delicious. The hotel is definitely as good as any four star hotel I have stayed in and I highly recommend it.

Jul 9 2005	Hospitality makes the stay!	I have never stayed at a hotel where I have been treated so nicely, and where the staff is accomodating and genuinely interested in helping you and making sure that you have everything that you need. Form early checkin to directions to wherever we wanted to go, the staff was ready and able to assist. The hotel is very nice, clean, and located close enough to anywhere you want to go. The Chicago experience involves the train and walking through beautiful downtown, and the location of this hotel gives you a chance ot experience the city that way. There are an abundance of local, non-chain restaurants within walking distance so you won't go hungry! The hotel also has its own restaurant that serves a delicious breakfast.

Jul 9 2005	Awesome experience	For visitors looking for an exciting offbeat vacation, the Silversmith is definitely the of the best hotel options in the city. If you are looking for cookie cutter rooms with bland furnishings, this is not the place for you. However, if you want to stay in the heart of the city, move with the people who live in this great city, this hotel offers a wonderful location and great staff. Several points to some of the other reviews:1) This isn't a Mich Ave hotel. It's in the business district and as such, isn't as touristy a location. However, you get a wonderfully restored, historic building designed by one of the city's master architects. The furnishings are nice and clean and very relaxing. 2) Yes, the el is right in front of the hotel. As in, you can stand on the L platform and see the entryway to the hotel. But this isn't a problem, if you want to go anywhere in the city. It's a great attribute for those people who don't need taxis to get around an urban setting.3) Noise...we stayed on the 8th floor in the back of the building. Despite some noise the first night, no earplugs were needed. The beds are very comfy and the bathrooms are something I could only wish I had at home. The hotel was VERY quite in general, though you can hear the slight noise of the urban setting. 4)This is NOT a bad part of town. I was with two other females and we walked everywhere at all times of the day and night. It's not as glitzy or busy as Michigan Ave, but you certainly don't need to freak out about walking down the street to go to a club or for dinner. Yes, there are a couple of people who work the lobby on the first floor/street level. But they are working, not bouncing the street in front of the building. They are getting luggage, helping customers and generally doing things that people pay huge bucks for in expensive hotels. I never once thought they were guarding the lobby.5) Early check in--- We arrived in the city via the L at 10am. We were helped inside (the doormen could hear us clanking down the steps of the El with our suitcases and were quick to help out). The doorman were excellent, offering a lot of advice for us since we were going to see the "Cubbies". The receptionist not only gave us an early check in (we'd asked for a place to store our luggage for the game)...but gave us a great room. In fact, I've never been in such a flexible hotel before. They definitely epitomize the word "accomodating". The staff in this hotel is unreal. When we left, the awesome doorman (one who carried two of our suitcases UP the L stairway when we voiced concerns about them being too heavy) always greeted us and offered umbrellas and advice without hesitation. The concierge was very helpful and so cheerful it was almost like being at cheer camp. But everyone in this hotel was awesome, friendly and helpful. I had a nice time just talking to them about the city and local places to visit/see. In comparison, we were sent to the poshest hotel on Mich Ave to get L passes from their gift shop. After waiting 20 minutes or longer in line at their conceirge desk (just to ask where the gift shop was)...we realized that spending more money on a hotel doesn't mean better service. If I had paid that much for a room and had to wait that long for someone to help me, I'd be mad. You will never wait more than a couple of minutes for anything at this hotel. Overall, this was a great trip. We looked forward to coming back to the room and resting between site seeing. And it's location to the lake front, shopping and museums means that you can go for short trips and the hotel is always just a few blocks away. If you have small children who need naps or just want to dump your shopping and go back out, this is the place to stay.We ate breakfast at Ada's several times. The meals were good and fairly priced, even if the staff seemed less than outgoing at times. But if you are looking for a quick start to the day with a wide option of meals, this is a good place to start.I have to say that I will probably never stay in another hotel while in Chicago. The quirkiness of this place is endearing. And trust me when I say that the best way to wind down from an exciting day is sitting in the lobby at night, munching on cheesecake, sipping the variety of coffees/teas and chatting with fellow guests. An excellent touch with great lighting, a soothing piano and really, a relaxing end to the day.I am a picky traveller and a picky sleeper. The rooms were comfortable and very clean. You can't do much better than this hotel. Trust the ratings and stay here. It was a wonderful urban experience.

Jul 7 2005	Location Location Location (and a great place too)	We chose the Crowne Plaza Silversmith for 2 main reasons:1) Location: within blocks from Millennium Park, Grant Park, Art Mus., etc. Since the weather was so nice we walked everywhere - Navy Pier, Water Tower, Sears Tower, Aquarium/Field Museum, Theater, etc. Marshall Fields is just blocks away as well as the Red Line subway/EL that takes you to Wrigley Field. EL is right out front that we did use a couple times since so convenient.2) Style: Arts & Craft/Mission style throughout the hotel. Great touches throughout lobby, halls, and into rooms. Bathroom very large w/ marble floors & counters. We had 2 room mini-suite with parlor with separate TV, desk, coffee table and sofa. 12 ft. high ceilings gives added appearance of spaciousness. Our huge windows even had a little view of Lake Michigan. So nice to see the sailboats and tour boats on the water.We tossed around the idea of staying closer to the Magnificent Mile area, but we are glad we didn't. It was nice to be in the heart of downtown, yet so close to the lake front and the parks. The Silversmith is a quaint, historic hotel with top notch staff. We always enjoyed being greeted by the bellmen & doormen whether we were coming or going. We'd definitely recommend this hotel to others and would stay here on our next trip to Chicago.

Jul 3 2005	Poor location service and facilities	This hotel was located in the downtown core but a long walk or train ride to the main restaurants and attractions on the North side. Service was below par, no flexibility of early checkin or late checkout. Limited lobby bar service offered with poor atmosphere and few drink selections.Lower floor rooms noisy due to proximity of the El train.Rooms clean and well decorated.Attached restaurant Ada's deli does good breakfast, didn't try evening meal. Miller's Bar is a short walk away and does an excellent evening meal (great ribs) for a reasonable price.

Jun 29 2005 	One of the best Chicago hotels!	Just stayed three nights at this fine, beautifully appointed hotel. Small suite on the 10th floor, wonderful furnishings, nicely served continental breakfast just down the hall. It is a small and perfectly situated hotel in the Loop area, walking distance to the Art Instititute, the new Millennium Park, and much more. It was a safe and busy neighborhood even until midnight, shopping, decent restaurants and theaters nearby.  A lovely lobby and small but excellent fitness center just off the lobby (clean and comfortable, windows out on to the street, treadmills, elliptical trainer and universal wieght machine and more.) Super friendly staff, too. I have stayed in a lot of hotels in Chicago, and this is definitely one of my favorites, for families or business, whatever.

Jun 19 2005	Truly wonderful	We paid extra for an executive room on the 10th floor. Our room was large with king size bed, lovely addition of a turn-down maid service each night with chocolates left on our pillows. Room was also supplied with earplugs, nightmask, lavendar spray and relaxation CD but only one kit - not that this was a problem. There was two bathrobes provided in the bathroom.We paid the additional rate for the room as included in the rate was continential breakfast - pastries, bagels, cereals, juices, tea/coffee which was supplied on our floor in a small meeting room.We could not see the L train from our room, as we were facing the back so did not have much of a view at all but at the same time we were not bothered by noise.The hotel is within walking distance of the main attractions of Chicago (well we walked to them!) and although not a particularly pleasant sight returning to the hotel at night-time but if you walk a block east, you come out by Grant Park which is wonderful and you do not feel like you are in the same city.We did not use any of the other facilities at the hotel nor did we get chance to sample the free cheesecake (but would have loved to) as we were still out at the time (and it is only served mon-thurs).Would highly recommend this hotel to everyone.

Jun 9 2005	Wonderful Hotel!	This hotel has recently been completely refurbished, rooms were very new looking and very clean. Beautiful rooms. The views stink, but the noise level was very minimal. I heard more traffic noise when staying at the Radisson last year on a higher floor. Request a room on one of the upper floors. We were on 7, and heard the "L" swoosh by but it wasn't a problem at all. No earplugs were needed. The staff was friendly and very accomadating, especially the door/bell men. Ada's restuarant next door is very reasonably priced. The only complaint was the slow elevators and that is not much to complain about. Oh and no cheesecake on the weekends.....bummer! But overall for the price we paid on the Crowne Plaza website, this was one of the more affordable rooms in the city in June, and we were very satisfied!

May 24 2005 	Holiday Inn Plus	The bottom line is that this is a Holiday Inn. A little nicer furnishings but basically a Holiday Inn. The biggest issue I have with the hotel is the location. It's right on Wabash and the "L" runs 20 feet away every 3-5 minutes. We had a room in the back which I requested and the "whooshing" sound went on forever. The noise is an annoyance, but not a prohibitive issue. Staff tries hard. All but one young man who works on Sundays and has an attitude. Management probably knows who he is. I won't give his name, but he's slight of build. Couple we were travelling with had a problem with a distinctly moldy smell in the room. They were finally moved, but it took a lot more arguing than it should have. And this was dealing with the manager, not my arrogant friend. Room rates seem to be all over the board on this place. Weekend rates can be reasonable or outrageous. We stayed for three nights. We had three rates and the highest rate was twice the lowest. And you don't get a lot of warm fuzzies walking on Wabash after dark. The hotel insists there's no problems, but they sure have plenty of security in the ground floor entry. In terms of hotel preference, the Silversmith ranks in about the middle of the pack of Chicago hotels.

Apr 28 2005	Loved it!!	My husband & I visited the Crowne Plaza Silversmith 4/20-4/23 and enjoyed ourselves immensely! We had researched a few options ahead of time and after reading previous Trip Advisor Reviews, decided on the CPS and were not disappointed... The reviews are not too good to be true... it's all factual. I'll breakdown as I can.Location - a block off of Michigan....so conveniently located near the Art Institute & a short cab ride from the Field Museum. In fact, if the weather hadn't been too cold, it would have been just fine to walk, too. Marshall Fields is just a block away.....that building is fantastic (it was not on my husband's "have to see" list but, after doing so, was appreciative since it is a spectacular building with interesting architecture.)Service - EXCELLENT!!! We were assisted with our bags the minute our cab dropped us off and escorted to the lobby area to check in (which just took minutes.) I did need just a few more hangers (but, that is because I over packed) and they were brought up within minutes. The concierge was wonderful. We visited in great length dinner options and she was very helpful with our sight-seeing discussion. The doormen were always most courteous and eager to "fetch a cab" for us, if need be. Service was just wonderful! The Suites - FABULOUS!! We did request a suite above the 5th floor - on the opposite side of the EL. I usually have a difficult time sleeping the first evening in a different location and had NO troubles catching a cat nap and falling into a wonderfully peaceful sleep my first night. The suites were very spacious and with the suite layout, allowed me to catch a few winks more than my "up at the crack of dawn" husband. I generally do not rave about bathrooms, but, these really were spectacular. The beautiful Granite countertops, spacious design with fluffy white robes to use...just wonderful! We enjoyed and appreciated the Relaxation CD.... we were supplied the Lavender linen spray and ear plugs but, neither were necessary. There is a slight "swoosh" noise from the El, but, it did not, in the least bit, cause disruption. The refrigerator was wonderful to store leftovers and bottled water..... The Lobby - LOVELY Mission style room. Not Grand in appearance (in comparison to a Palmer House for example) but, lovely. They had a cheesecake hour I believe at 9:00 M-TH, however, we were always out & about at that time but, it is there for the guests. The fitness center (which we did not use) was adjacent to the lobby and easily accessible, if one so desired. Quiet, Relaxing & Enjoyable area. As I said, previously, just Lovely! Restaurants - Nothing to share, here. We were travelling with others and we did not ever seem to make it to Ada's Deli/Restaurant. However, did make it over (1/2 block away) to the Corner Bakery Cafe for a sandwich a couple of times....what a wonderful lunch or breakfast menu. We went to Miller's Pub one evening for a quick bite....one can't eat heavy, rich foods, every night so.... and Miller's Pub was a fun setting with good burgers ( my husband had a hamburger & I had a turkey burger) and it was exactly what the doctor ordered for us, that day. Trader Vic's was fabulous... a bit pricey but, very good. Now, if you get the opportunity to get over to Greek Town, please go to Costa's.....FABULOUS!!!!! Their menu was tremendous, the food was DELICIOUS, and setting was just FUN & very ENJOYABLE!!Overall, just a fabulous experience at the CPS! We would definitely stay there again. Now, if we could have only brought wonderful weather with us, the trip would have been perfect!!

Mar 17 2005	Struck gold at the Silversmith	Wonderful room, service, location. I don't know how they perch a hotel right over the L tracks without noise problems, but that is the case. A helpful staff, easy going yet elegant atmosphere, and an overall great bargain. Very reasonable with a terrific concierge.

Mar 16 2005 	Like a perfect dream.....	Like the others said, I had a bit of trouble finding the hotel, from the views from its website, it appears grand and elaborate, however, the entrance is simple and discreet. I called for directions and the front desk agent stayed on the phone with me and coached me in as I twisted through the city. I was a bit apprehensive about the experience until this moment when they actually spent 10 minutes with me helping me find the hotel. When I finally found the hotel I questioned myself because the entrance is an old drab hallway with 3 elevators. There was nothing else other than the cheery doorman who greeted me as I came in and directed me upstairs to check in. As the elevator opened, I saw the lobby - WOW - a hidden treasure! The room was spectacular - the view wasn't, just a birdseye view of the train, but the service made up for it and more! Remember these names - MICHAEL and PEGGY. These two are remarkable! When you go, you must meet these two people. The train noise is minimal and they give you earplugs and music to help subdue the sound. All in all, outstanding place!

Mar 9 2005 	Old a bit drab but great location and service	When I checked in, the staff could not be friendlier - they even have a reception at 9pm with FREE cheese cake, coffee and cookies. the rooms are large and they provide nice amenities, but the views are horrible. My room faced a brick wall and my friend's room faced the "L" which was noisy! They do provide earplugs, but if you are not used to sleeping with them you will not be happy.The location is good for business travelers. they gym stinks - an old stairmaster, bike and treadmill - not worth putting on my sneakers. Overall, if you can get a good rate and don't need much, go for it.

Mar 3 2005	Gorgeous decor kind staff great location for theater	4 adults stayed in a room with 2 "double" beds in mid-January. The beds looked more like queen size. We also had a roll-away so we could spread out a little - no charge. What a pretty mission-style room. And the bathroom was unbelievable...so huge we set-up the ironing board in there for the duration. The room rate was around $120/night. Valet parking (the only option) is $28/day - which is unfortunate but normal for downtown Chicago. Breakfast was not included in our rate. Attended a show at the Shubert and chose this hotel for its proximity to the theater and its lower rates. In the bitter cold we were able to walk to the theater (even grandma!) Also walked to Trader Vic's for dinner and the younger folks walked to the Art Institute. (In better weather, anyone should be able to make the walk.) Walking distance to Marshall Field's - it's basically right next door. There is a restaurant/deli in the same building so you don't even have to go outside. The staff were all really kind and helpful. We felt like the only guests at the hotel. In fact, I didn't hear any noise for 3 days! All rooms have a fridge, CD player, relaxation CD's, linen spray and earplugs - a nice touch. The el-train noise was not noticable. Requested a room above the 5th floor on the recommendation of another reviewer. Good advice! Join the Priority Club to earn points toward a free stay at Holiday Inn, Intercontinental, Crowne Plaza hotels - it's free.

Mar 3 2005	Quiet Friendly Great Location	After reading a number of reviews of downtown's "budget" hotels on tripadvisor, we decided to splurge a little and go for the Silversmith - and we were not disappointed! Not having stayed in Chicago before, we were pleasantly surprised at how very quiet this hotel is. We took the advice of other reviewers and requested a room away from the El train, and it was just an occasional, 5-second, distant "whoosh" sound. It's nothing compared to the experience of staying in a hotel with an in-room blower! We couldn't even hear sounds from the street - It was amazingly quiet for being right downtown. That downtown location was equidistant from everything we wanted to see & do - It's just a couple blocks from the Art Institute, Millenium Park (note that the Cloud Gate is under construction until spring), and the absolutely wonderful Berghoff restaurant. The room itself was super clean, well-appointed, nice high ceilings/windows, big bathroom, and comfy bed with lots of pillows. The hotel staff were all very courteous and friendly - When we mentioned to the front desk attendant that we would be stopping at the Museum of Science & Industry on our way out of town, he gave us a pair of free passes that he happened to have that day! We found the hotel & the city very accessible, with a nice, hometown feel that you don't find in places like NYC. The attached restaurant, Ada's, was also very good and reasonably priced, with great service. Try the potato pancakes! Overall an excellent experience.

Jan 26 2005	Great value great staff - outstanding!	We stayed at the Silversmith for 5 days last September, based largely on recommendations from other TripAdvisor users. We owe them a debt of gratitude! The Silversmith is a lovely, well-appointed hotel with great staff. It's decorated in a turn-of-the-20th century Arts and Crafts manner, rather more interesting than the bland "corporate modern" decor of many hotels. It's in a very convenient location - we were able to walk to many attractions - Grant Park, the lakefront, the Art Institute and Michigan Avenue are all within a short walk, as is State Street shopping. And the train stations are very close as well, meaning you can get anywhere (even O'Hare!) in good order, and cheaply. I think we took a cab once in five days.The staff is very helpful without being obsequious, happy to assist with any questions or needs you have. Perfect. The continental breakfast (incl. with our room) was wonderful, the evening dessert buffet was lovely, the bed was ultra-comfortable, the bathroom was *very* large, and...what else can I say? A+

Jan 25 2005	Comfortable quiet friendly. Lousy window view.	My husband and I stayed one night on Saturday Jan 22 and were very satisfied with the Silversmith. The personnel were fantastic - very friendly. The woman who staffed the little desk in front of the door went way out of her way when our taxi didn't arrive on time to take us to the airport. She actually went out in the snow on a COLD Sunday morning to grab us a taxi waiting at another hotel around the corner at 5AM. The rest of the staff was also very cordial. Our remote wasn't working properly, and they had a new one to us within a couple minutes of my call. The woman who brought it waited outside our door until I verified it worked and came back out to let her know. The doorman was all smiles and cheer too.The room was on the 8th floor (nice), but had a view of brick walls (what a shame). MOST importantly, it was VERY comfortable, and quiet. We didn't like the lavendar linen spray, but did play the relaxation CD which was nice. The fridge was handy for leftovers, though a microwave would have been nice for the late night snack.The location was great for us - a great middle stop for hiking to the sights we wanted to visit to both the north and south.

Jan 25 2005	reviews are true	We went to Chicago the week of January 17th to visit family. I chose this hotel because of the reviews on trip advisor. We were travelling with our 17 month old son and so it was very important to us to find a hotel that had suites and was also affordable. This hotel was perfect. The room was large and had a separate bedroom. It also had a refrigerator in the room which was very convenient. We asked for a room on the opposite side from the train and it was very quiet. Still had some train noise, but unless you are extremely sensitive to noise it was hardly noticeable. Everyone was extremely friendly and helpful. The room was very clean and comfortable. We ended up staying an extra day and they gave us a reduced rate for the extra night. Only negative to this hotel is location. Because it was so cold we took a taxi everywhere we went. It is off the beaten track, but still close enough to walk if the weather is warmer. Most of our taxi fares were under $8.00. All in all a great hotel.

Jan 8 2005	Great New Year's stay	My sister, nephew, & I stayed at this hotel over New Year's Eve. We got a great rate for both the night before & New Year's Eve by booking on Crowne Plaza's website in advance. The hotel is several blocks away from Shubert theatre where we had tickets to a show. The location is great. We drove in from the Detroit area and had a hard time finding the hotel. Look closely, because the only part of the hotel at street level is the front door. Once we found it we had a great stay. The front desk staff were very helpful and pleasant. The concierge, Peggy, was a delight. The room was big enough for the three of us, and we appreciated the relaxation CD since we were just above the train (on the 5th floor). Although you could hear it, the noise was not that loud. The room was very clean and well appointed. It had the largest safe I've ever had in a hotel. One note--if you plan to use the sofa bed, let them know when you check in. Although they had turndown service, they did not pull out the sofa bed for my nephew. When we pulled it out, we found it did not have linens on it. We called the front desk and they told us you need to inform them if you want to use the sofa bed. When we checked in they knew we were 2 adult women and one large 16 year old boy--I felt they should have known that we would not all fit in 1 king size bed. That was the only hiccup in a great stay. Oh, Ada's Deli in the hotel has the best potato chips if you like your chips well-done (not quite burnt). They make them there. Be sure to stock up.

Jan 4 2005	Crown Plaza Silversmith a true gem!	What a great hotel for a downtown location. Marshall Fields is a block away! The service at this hotel was great! We had made modifications to our reservations and had no problems whatsoever! We had a suite on the 8th floor. Huge bathroom (with terry robes!). Pull-out couch for the son, and a wonderful king bed in a seperate room for mom and dad! Coffee maker, fridge, and turn-down service with mints! We highly recommend using the concierge. She had some great tips for us as well as having connections for quick seating at the Walnut Room (even during the holidays!).We requested a room opposite the train system - and it was very quiet. However, they provided a set of earplugs if needed, along with a CD to help you sleep.For a downtown location - we would definitely go back!

Jan 2 2005	A Vacation Highlight	This hotel was wonderful -- it became a highlight of our short vacation in Chicago. We had a suite on the 5th floor - with an interesting view of the El and Wabash Street. Yes, there is some noise from the El, but the windows are well insulated, and the suite contained earplugs, lavender linen spray, and a relaxation CD -- all of which helped us to forget the noise and just enjoy the room. Great location and wonderful service. Well recommended!

Dec 29 2004 	Great Hotel	I stayed here a few months ago. Had to be in town on business short notice initially could only get into the SuisseHotel which was nice but extremely pricey. I managed to get into the Silversmith by virtue of being platinum with Priority Club. I was not upgraded as the hotel was extremely full at the time however I was given access to the club lounge for free breakfast etc if I wanted it (unfortunately was also working a wierd hours shift and don't think I ever at a breakfast while in town). The doormen are all extremely friendly helping with getting your bags from cabs and saying hi and it seems like they mean it as well when you walk in and out of the hotel. The front desk manager was extremely nice and very accomodating with any requests that I had. They even went as far as letting me use their office PC's when I could not get their business center PC's to print out my boarding pass. The restaurant downstairs is nothing spectacular just good normal American type food (I personally liked it as I like being able to get something that looks regular when I'm in a rush). The room was not very large however the hotel is an old remodeled building that has these 12' ceilings so it gives the impression that the room is huge regardless of the square footage. I plan on staying there again if sent to the Windy City for business and hope to take my wife there someday if we go on vacation to Chicago.

Nov 28 2004	What a GREAT Hotel 	I initially made our Chicago reservations at the Hotel Allegro, but after reading all the negative reviews regarding noise level between rooms, I made reservations with the Chicago Silversmith. We visited Chicago Nov 20-25 for vacation. The reviews were right on the mark -- this place is a FANTASTIC find!! I called prior to our arrival and asked for a room on the fifth floor or higher -- due to the noise level of the El train. When we arrived at 10:00 am, we were given a suite on the 10th floor, Club Level. Our suite was huge with wonderful big windows and mission style furniture (our favorite). This is a perfect hotel for families. There were three of us. Mom & Dad in the bedroom and child in the living room (queen sleeper sofa). The bathroom was also huge. Our $153 rate included continental breakfast that was located a couple doors down from our room. It was staffed by a Silversmith employee. She prepared our coffee and any items we wanted heated or toasted. We also had the opportunity to use the Concierge (Peggy) several times. She was very knowledgeable and friendly. The entire hotel staff was top notch. The location of this hotel is perfect. There are plenty of great places to eat (the Berghoff is one of our favorites) and lots of museums and shopping. The Art Institute is just a couple of blocks away. We also walked to the Field Museum and to the north end of Michigan Ave to the John Hancock Building. We rode the El (right outside our door) to visit Oak Park -- home of Frank Lloyd Wright. We will definitely recommend the Silversmith to our friends and hope to stay again in the near future.

Nov 17 2004 	I just pray they don't jack up their rates like everyone else!!!	This hotel is, in a word, superb. As a party of four, we rented a King Suite, which is a king size bed plus a fold-out queen size couch bed. My wife and I slept on the latter and it was very comfortable--no bar in the back syndrome. The couple who got the bed raved at its comfort. The bathroom was huge, and the shower terrific. Even though our room faced Wabash and thus the train, while it could be heard going by the windows were insulated well enough that it wasn't too much of a disturbance. The style and cleanliness of the hotel were excellent. The service and staff were wonderful. Also, the hotel doesn't nickel and dime you to death for every amenity you desire. I will definitely stay here every time I go to Chicago unless they, like every other great place I find, start jacking up their rates. Our suite was $136 + tax per night, and we were 100% satisfied. Please keep rates reasonable and we will keep coming back!!!

Nov 16 2004	A Wonderful Place to Stay	We just had a great weekend in Chicago and stayed at the Silversmith for three nights. My first clue this would be a restful retreat was the understated entrance to the hotel. Simply a door off Wabash Ave. that leads to the elevators for the hotel located in one of Chicago's historic buildings. The room was beautiful, muted colors, very comfortable bed and sofa. A huge bathroom with separate tub and shower. Incredible tall thin windows with not much of a view but...Perfect Perfect Perfect. Yes, we could hear the trains going by but we just pretended it was the North Wind.The location was excellent for what we had in mind. Close to Trader Vic's at the Palmer House, Millenium Park, the Art Institute, Marshall Fields window displays, shopping, food. We walked everywhere we needed to go. Never felt the need to take the train. Paid $28 per night for valet parking and well worth it to us. Just knowing we could have the car whenever we wanted was great...even though we never needed it.Walked to Sears Tower, walked to John Hancock, all from this centrally located hotel.Plus there is an excellent deli located on the bottom floor where the Rueben's are to die for.Give this hotel a shot and you will be assured of stress-free stay.

Nov 2 2004	Good value for the $	Very nice, clean hotel that must have been recently renovated. Great location, exception for being right next to the L train (very loud). That's the biggest negative. Other than that, excellent service. Paid $171/night for a suite on the concierge level. Well worth the money.

Nov 2 2004	Once again-A1 Service!!	I stayed at the Crowne Plaza-Silversmith a year ago and had excellent service that I decided to take my girlfriend with me this past weekend. My girlfriends absolutely loved it!! The staff was very professional and helpful. Our rooms where very clean and roomy. Many hotels in Chicago have very small rooms but ours where a good size. The front desk was very friendly. It is located by all of the major shopping stores, so we walked instead of being bother with traffic. I have nothing bad to say about Crowne Plaza-Silversmith. This is the only place I will stay!!

Oct 20 2004	a gem under the el tracks	The Silversmith is quite the find. It's a small, boutique-ish hotel in the loop, right next to the Madison El station and a little over a block from the grand old Marshall Field's store.The lobby is small and elegant, decorated in traditional furniture. The traditional look continues in the rooms, which are large with huge TVs in armoires, CD player-clocks and other niceties. The bathrooms are also big, with plenty of fluffy towels.But it's the service that really sets this place apart. The doormen are the absolute best, greeting you every time you enter and literally breaking their necks to help you with bags. Also, there's turn down service, a little sleeping aid bag with an eyemask and CD, and even a call from the front desk after you've checked in.The Loop location isn't the most lively on nights and weekends, but the Silversmith is in a great spot. You can literally walk out the front door and up the stairs of the El station (Brown, Green, Purple and Orange lines). The red line is a block away on State Street, and another block over is the Blue Line to O'Hare. The hotel is also within easy walking distance of Millenium Park and the museums, or even the Mag Mile on a decent day. (Save the shoe leather and take the red line up to Chicago for the Mag Mile tho).With rates that haven't gone bonzo like many Chicago hotels, the Silversmith is a jewel. I can't say enough good things about this place!

Oct 3 2004	Crowne Plaza Silversmith - Great Price Great Place	After weeks of searching for the best hotel to stay at in Chicago along with the best price I followed the advice of other reviews from Trip Advisor and I was not disappointed at all. The Crowne Plaza Silversmith was a wonderful place to stay. Not only was the location convienient to many Chicago attractions, the staff was outstanding. My family and I were treated like royalty. The hotel staff were professional, personable and are willing to do whatever it takes to make your stay comfortable. The hotel is immaculate, everything was clean and in perfect condition from the lobby to the hotel rooms. The decor is tastefully done and well maintained. We had a suite and it was very roomy and comfortable, we felt at home in this room. The beds and bedding are very plush and cozy. They even provide you with a music CD to help you sleep. The bathroom was very nice and large. Best of all the price was very reasonable compared to other hotels in the area. The one and only complaint I have is that the hotel is located next to the Loop and depending where your room is located you can hear a faint sound of the train. I followed other travelers suggestions and requested a room on an upper floor not facing the loop and it was fine. Also, we took the blue line train from the airport for $1.75 each and it stopped about 2 blocks from the hotel which saved us about $50.00 in cab fare. All our luggage has wheels so it wasn't a problem walking from the train station. I felt we got a great value, outstanding service and a perfect location convienient to shopping, restaurants and attractions. I highly recommend this hotel, you won't be disappointed!

Sep 11 2004	Great Service/Great Hotel	We just returned from a four night stay at the Silversmith, which I booked largely based on recommendations from TripAdvisor users. We were very impressed. The hotel had a lovely lobby and great rooms: large(!), clean, with stylish/comfortable furnishings, and roomy window seats and sills (which the kids loved). The staff was super friendly and accomodating. The hotel is about 2 blocks from the new Millennium Park, which was a big hit! A longer but nice walk from the hotel to the museum campus and a quick cab ride to other sites, like Lincoln Park Zoo and MOSI. For a family, the location was great: right near a CVS pharmacy, a Corner Bakery cafe, and a White Hen convenience store. It's also right next to the El (or the flying train, according to my daughter), but there was no real noise. Security was nice, too--you need a room key to access all floors but the lobby. I would definitely recommend the Silversmith.

Aug 30 2004	A wonderful place for families	Just returned from a comfortable stay at the Crowne Plaza Silversmith. The location was exceptionally convenient, the staff was attentive and friendly, and the room was spotless. The blue line from O'Hare is 2 blocks away, all other lines are either out the front door or 1 black away, and there's a free green trolley(to the Aquarium) stop about 2 blocks away. Our executive floor room well-suited our family's needs with a large granite bathroom, a small breakfast buffet, and a refrigerator. In the lounge, available to all guests is a basket of apples and oranges, morning coffee, and on Monday-Thurs. there is evening dessert. The decor is tasteful and understated. Our only complaint was that our room faced a tall brick wall, so that we had no view, and the natural lighting was limited. But really, we weren't in the room much, so it wasn't a big deal. We would definitely stay there again.

Aug 14 2004 	Great hotel great location	I had a good experience in August at The Crowne Plaza Silversmith. I got a deal through their website and a further discounted rate on the weekend for the concierge floor. The only real extra, besides needing your key card to access the floor, is a free breakfast buffet of the usual pastries, cereal, yogurt, fruit and coffee served on the floor. There is a micro and toaster you can use during breakfast in the floors lounge. High speed wired internet also.The hotel is right in front of the "L" subway trains, which are noisy and run regularly. Thankfully the hotel has excellent windows that do a good job of muting almost all the sound. The hotel is done in a mission style with lots of oak and architectural accents. Perfect if you're on a Frank Lloyd Wright-themed trip.The rooms are high-ceilinged and large with big windows. The site said the last renovation was in 1998, but it has held up well. The only blemish was an older shower head that wasn't as powerful as I would have liked.Location is excellent - one block from Grant park, the bandshell, Art Institute, Marshall Fields and other shopping. Also within 2 blocks of the L trains for Midway and O'Hare airports. The deli/restaurant downstairs is open late, has a wide variety of food from premium hotdogs to giant sandwiches to steak. The desserts and their own root beer are excellent.All in all a great hotel - worth the money.

Jul 27 2004 	Great stay	We had a wonderful time at this hotel. The staff was pleasant and the concierge was so very helpful in finding restaurants that really gave us a feel for Chicago's cuisine. Nov 15 2009 	Great Suite in Best Location	We have 2 young children so we stayed in a king one bedroom suite with adjoining standard room. This gave us two seperate bedrooms and a living room w/desk. Nov 15 2009 	Comfort and Location	Stayed for 5 nights in October to celebrate my husbands 50th birthday. Doormen and bell boys were excellent. Front desk staff a little aloof but professional. Nov 10 2009 	Wonderful experience	We first want to congratulate and thank their concierge staff. Before we even got there, Stephanie was a huge help. The bellmen during check in and during our trip were very friendly and helpful. The Room was great. Well cleaned but when we had used some coffee mugs and glasses it took them a while to replace. There is a restuarant on premise called Bice Bistro. We got back from our restaurant on Saturday night at about eleven and the bar was closed. We were told Talbot was not a destination place. Seems like if they marketed that more, it would be another revenue stream, especially with all the new condos and apartments in the area. Now to the wourse part of the Talbot. That breakfast you get when you register on line is not worth it at all. Continetal breakfasts at Holiday Inn Express, Hilton Gardens etc are much better. In fact, if I were the Talbot I wouldn't do it. No fruit, cereal that was for kids, restocking for bowls for cereal, no bagels, just toast. We ate there one of three mornings and that was all we could take.We loved the Frette bedding and towels. Top notch. Aveda products were terrific also. . We loved the location. Kind of a quiet side street. Heard a lot from folks on this message board about construction. Yes it is going on but it is not the Talbot's fault. It isn't that bad anyhow. Finally we had a temperature problem and hair dryer problem with our room and when we called, it was fixed right away.It was a great three days.

Nov 2 2009 	Bring an alarm clock	My girlfriend and I were there for a weekend at the end of October. The room was clean but you could see it had seen better days. Nov 2 2009 	Had Great stay at the Talbott!	From the moment I arrived, I was treated like an honored guest. Oct 29 2009 	Great hotel in a great location.	My husband and I recently stayed at the Talbott for 6 nights and thoroughly enjoyed it. Our room was a "Deluxe Parlor King" which the Web site says is 520 sq ft. The room was HUGE, which made it very comfortable for an extended stay. (Our room appeared to be a handicapped accessible room which makes me wonder if it was even a little larger than that type of room would normally be.) The bathroom was very large also, with a separate tub and shower and Aveda products. The towels were nicer than our towels at home. The place was very clean and the staff was friendly and helpful. The hotel was just a couple of blocks from Michigan Avenue so it was close to lots of great shopping, restaurants and sites. The free breakfast was okay if you like to keep it simple in the morning (toast/croissants, yogurt, lunch meats & cheeses, cereal). If you need a little more, there is a great diner nearby (Tempo Cafe), a place across the street and a Starbuck's in the area. Be sure to also hit the fabulous cupcake shop (More) down the street. One thing that we didn't like was the Business Center. This consisted of one computer which you had to pay to use in 15 minute increments and then pay for copies also. It's free to use for printing boarding passes, but I didn't realize that until after I spent $7 to print ours. Next time, I'll just take a laptop. Despite this, we had a wonderful time at this hotel and will stay there next time we visit Chicago.

Oct 29 2009 	Unbelievable value great location..definitely will stay again	The Talbott Hotel was exactly what we were looking for. The Talbott is located in a wonderful location (except for construction...I'll talk about that later). It is a very short walk to Magnificant Mile, Oak Street, the lake and just a couple of streets away from a Metro Stop. It is also a five minute walk to some great restaurants (Gibson's, etc.). There are plenty of places to eat and grab a cup of coffee (i need my starbucks in the morning and there is one across the street) near the hotel. In addition to the great location is the value. We booked this hotel for well below what most hotels in the area were asking and it surpassed our expectations. The rooms were a decent size and included a flat screen television, comfy beds, turndown service and great toiletries. Most importantly, the hotel was very clean.My only concerns were as follows: 1) The hotel is located next to some high rises that are currently under construction and unfortunately our room faced the construction so we were subject to some construction noises in the morning. Nothing unbearable, but obvious. 2) The bellman and doormen were extremely friendly and willing to assist, but some of the front desk attendants seemed somewhat indifferent. I'm not saying they were rude, just not as eager to assist and friendly as I thought they might be (there were one or two exceptions of course). 3) I initially called the hotel to inquire about the best rate guarantee and it seemed as if no one fully understood it at the reservation desk except the manager who called me back later to explain it. I think everyone taking reservations should have a full understanding of the guarantee and how it works, otherwise don't market it. The Talbott isn't the exception here, it seems many hotels put price guarantees on their websites and then when you call to take them up on it the reservation desk often don't know what the policy is or tell you the wrong policy.Overall, I would stay here again and probably request a room facing the front of the building (away from construction). It is a very cozy hotel in a great location.

Sep 28 2009 	Elegance in the city	We stayed at the Chicago Talbott in August 2009. Jul 19 2009 	A comfortable and warm stay	My wife and I took a trip to Chicago to celebrate our 30th birthdays and had heard great things about The Talbott, and were able to get a decent rate on a single room suite. Arriving at the hotel we were greeted by the doorman with the biggest smile that never went away during our entire stay. We actually arrived around 9am and they were able to get us into our suite without issue which was a huge plus. They also surprised us with complimentary daily breakfasts because we reserved our room through their site.The hotel its self is bit older but has been well maintained, and still has the warm feeling that you really dont get from newer more modern places. The room was outstanding with a huge living space, what seemed like an even larger bathroom, and a great bedroom. The king bed was one of the best that I have ever slept on; my wife had the same thought. The bathroom which is covered in marble had a separate room for the toilet, a large bathtub, a large glass shower and three sinks. Two of them are together while the other is on the opposite side of the bathroom which is quite nice if there are two people getting ready at the same time.The location is optimal and basically walking distance from everything. Its a few blocks from the Magnificent Mile, few blocks from the Hancock building, and a decent walk to the Navy Pier. The street its on gets a bit crowed as they are doing construction next door (which we never heard), but as long as you cross with the lights, youll be fine.I definitely recommend giving The Talbott a try if you want a nice warm, almost like home feeling, while still right in the heart of all the action.

Nov 13 2008 	Wonderful intimate hotel!	My wife and I recently enjoyed a couple of days in Chicago to see a play and fully enjoyed our experience at the Talbott. Initially, I was worried about the service due to the concierge's inability to return my e-mails in reference to ordering flowers for my wife, but after a call to the hotel, the concierge was more than helpful and the arrangement ordered was absolutely perfect. The lobby is small (or intimate as you prefer), so if you like to feel anonymous as you enter or leave, this is not the hotel for you. Doormen, bellmen, and receptionists WILL be attending to your needs or wishing you well with big smiles. Being an older hotel, sometimes there is a wait for an elevator (they're slow and small), but not overly so. The rooms were spacious and clean, and the bathroom in our suite was huge and absolutely gorgeous (we'll be remodeling ours soon). My wife visited Lush and the Body Shop for supplies and took no less then three baths during our stay. Our bed was absolutely comfortable. I would agree with others that there is quite a bit of construction in the area (like right next door!), but in reality, we hardly noticed it. If you hear a hammer, turn on the Ipod ready radio or the 42" widescreen TV. It IS the city, after all. The location is wonderful! Only a couple minute stroll to Water Tower Place and an $8.00 cab ride to the Oriental Theater. On the whole, our stay was wonderful and an absolute bargain compared with other hotels in the area. We'll be back.
